thread.title: WIP - Some textures ( floor / wall / lights ... )

post.author: elusive
post.body:
Hey guys!

I'm working on some textures at the moment and thinking about making a kind of texture pack. If so I'd have to do some more

Here are some screens. Hope you like them

(If the picture size doesn't fullfill the forum requirements I will remove them and just add the links)

post.author: =NoMercy=
post.body: Those look very nice! keep it up!

post.author: Skutarth
post.body:
Very comparable to id Software's own textures.

Actually, they remind a bit of Prey.

post.author: BJA
post.body: Very nice stuff. I especially like the third one.

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body: nice, could we see some wireframes of the low poly versions or are they just normal mapped rectangles?

post.author: elusive
post.body:
Thanks for comments!
These are all texture normalmaps. They're just brushes with the textures assigned. I'm working on some new ones at the moment. I'll post some screenshots soon

post.author: mikebart
post.body: they look realy nice, is the third one a door? could you show the maps themselves?

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body: understood and cool

post.author: elusive
post.body:
Quote:
they look realy nice, is the third one a door? could you show the maps themselves?


Well the third one was not supposed to be a door but a kind of wall texture. But thinking about it you could also use it as a door.

I loaded up the maps.
Localmap:


Diffusemap:


Specularmap:


And another one

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body: interesting and your new one looks cool

post.author: mikebart
post.body: they look really nice

post.author: elusive
post.body:
Thanks!
I need to do more trims and such. Before I started mapping for Doom3 engine games i didn't know how useful those textures can be. Since texturing today is different than in the past ...

If you want to suggest textures you'd need don't hesitate to tell me
Only thing is that the color schemes have to fit together.

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body: how about some high tech archway textures? ie for use on brushwork rather then models.

post.author: elusive
post.body:
Sure I can do that!
Still have to figure out how to bring a round shape for an archway in harmony with non-gothic high tech environment ...

post.author: Lumpengnom
post.body:
That are some nice textures.

elusive wrote:
Sure I can do that!
Still have to figure out how to bring a round shape for an archway in harmony with non-gothic high tech environment ...


There are lots of good examples for round arch constructions in modern architecture.
Check out Alameda subway station in Valencia by Santiago Calatrava for that. Fosters Faculty of Law in Cambridge is a nice example for a modern arch construction as well. And then there´s an awesome industrial building by Samyn and Partners in Belgium.

All of theser are not the typical doomesque hightech style but you can extrapolate from there.

post.author: elusive
post.body: cool! Thanks! I'll keep that in mind and see what I can find!

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body: cool

post.author: m!chi:be
post.body:
good work but i like the last one most.
the others are shining a little bit to blueish for my taste.

post.author: mikebart
post.body: How did you go about the dents and gouge marks on the normal map? some more distressed versions of the ones you've already done would look pretty sweet.

post.author: elusive
post.body:
Dents, scratches and flaked off paint are all done using a heightmap. The basic structure comes from the normalmap.
In some cases I use a detail texture to give them a look like in UT.

Quote:
some more distressed versions of the ones you've already done would look pretty sweet.


Do you mean some versions which look more rotten?

post.author: Skutarth
post.body:
Move some of your scratches from the diffuse to the specular map.
Since a lot of these are metal, it makes sense for the scratches to sheen.

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
elusive wrote:
Dents, scratches and flaked off paint are all done using a heightmap. The basic structure comes from the normalmap.
In some cases I use a detail texture to give them a look like in UT.

Quote:
some more distressed versions of the ones you've already done would look pretty sweet.


Do you mean some versions which look more rotten?


yeah, maybe you could wear them down even more, remove some parts/panels of the textures exposing cables/machinery behind them, go a bit deeper into the wall these panels are covering.
You've got some realy nice base models/textures to play around with and I think this whole theme you're working on could be developed alot further with some experimentation.

post.author: elusive
post.body:
@Skutarth
Yes. I usually do that but sometimes the results are not clearly visible in Doom. I'll work on that.

@mikebart
Good points! That makes me curious how it would look like ingame ;D

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body: elusive, I really like mikebart's suggestion, that could also be interesting to see bump mapped cables and machine parts behind some of the removed panels. you might even consider coloring them differently, so the cables were even more obvious. all up to you of course but I'd like to see some tests at least

post.author: elusive
post.body:
I'll work on it as far as possible!
Doing cables and complex tech stuff behind wall panel is a bit more to model than a plane with some extruded faces

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body: understood and at least you like mikebart's suggestion

post.author: elusive
post.body:
Alright I started making such a kind of model that has some pipes and stuff behind a panel.
It still needs details but I'd like to show you what I got so far

post.author: Bo$bevok
post.body:
omg thats gonna look so awesome ingame...
keep up the good work

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body:
elusive, its cool but I would make the exposed pipes less straight, ie have more bends in them.

also I'm not sure about the wires coming out of one panel opening and leading into another, I think I would of made them hang out of just the one on the left.

keep up the good work though, this will look very impressive when finished

post.author: elusive
post.body:
Thanks for the suggestion and comments!

@ratty redemption
You mean I should add a curve to two of the pipes behind? If so no problem
I'll experiment with those cables a bit. I'll show an update to the model when I'm back home from work!

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body:
elusive wrote:
You mean I should add a curve to two of the pipes behind? If so no problem
I'll experiment with those cables a bit. I'll show an update to the model when I'm back home from work!

cool and yes, I think that would make them look more interesting and natural.

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
that looks nice, I definitly agree with ratty about the pipes.
have you thought about baking a mask for behind the panel? Im not sure what app you're using for projection but if you can assign different colours to the high poly model you could bake some masks which could then be selected in photoshop.

What apps are you using?, have you looked into ambient occlusion?

post.author: elusive
post.body:
I think ambient occlusion should be enough to mask the pipes behind the panel for the diffuse. If you have any tipps according to that method just fire
I use Maya and Photoshop for my work.
It has some nice features for texture baking. I'm still trying to figure out how to get the best results. The rest will be painted with a tablet usually.

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
oh ok, theres ao on your textures already? I think I can see it now

I dont have any tips on ao really, but id definitly recommend experimenting with the projection tool in maya, I havent used the maya one personally but im sure its the same, in max I use it to do all sorts of things, from skyboxes to rendering alpha planes and masks and then there are so many ideas I have which I havent even gotten around to trying yet, it can be a very powerful tool.

post.body: How did you go about the dents and gouge marks on the normal map? some more distressed versions of the ones you've already done would look pretty sweet.

post.author: elusive
post.body:
Dents, scratches and flaked off paint are all done using a heightmap. The basic structure comes from the normalmap.
In some cases I use a detail texture to give them a look like in UT.

Quote:
some more distressed versions of the ones you've already done would look pretty sweet.


Do you mean some versions which look more rotten?

post.author: Skutarth
post.body:
Move some of your scratches from the diffuse to the specular map.
Since a lot of these are metal, it makes sense for the scratches to sheen.

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
elusive wrote:
Dents, scratches and flaked off paint are all done using a heightmap. The basic structure comes from the normalmap.
In some cases I use a detail texture to give them a look like in UT.

Quote:
some more distressed versions of the ones you've already done would look pretty sweet.


Do you mean some versions which look more rotten?


yeah, maybe you could wear them down even more, remove some parts/panels of the textures exposing cables/machinery behind them, go a bit deeper into the wall these panels are covering.
You've got some realy nice base models/textures to play around with and I think this whole theme you're working on could be developed alot further with some experimentation.

post.author: elusive
post.body:
@Skutarth
Yes. I usually do that but sometimes the results are not clearly visible in Doom. I'll work on that.

@mikebart
Good points! That makes me curious how it would look like ingame ;D

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body: elusive, I really like mikebart's suggestion, that could also be interesting to see bump mapped cables and machine parts behind some of the removed panels. you might even consider coloring them differently, so the cables were even more obvious. all up to you of course but I'd like to see some tests at least

post.author: elusive
post.body:
I'll work on it as far as possible!
Doing cables and complex tech stuff behind wall panel is a bit more to model than a plane with some extruded faces

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body: understood and at least you like mikebart's suggestion

post.author: elusive
post.body:
Alright I started making such a kind of model that has some pipes and stuff behind a panel.
It still needs details but I'd like to show you what I got so far

post.author: Bo$bevok
post.body:
omg thats gonna look so awesome ingame...
keep up the good work

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body:
elusive, its cool but I would make the exposed pipes less straight, ie have more bends in them.

also I'm not sure about the wires coming out of one panel opening and leading into another, I think I would of made them hang out of just the one on the left.

keep up the good work though, this will look very impressive when finished

post.author: elusive
post.body:
Thanks for the suggestion and comments!

@ratty redemption
You mean I should add a curve to two of the pipes behind? If so no problem
I'll experiment with those cables a bit. I'll show an update to the model when I'm back home from work!

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body:
elusive wrote:
You mean I should add a curve to two of the pipes behind? If so no problem
I'll experiment with those cables a bit. I'll show an update to the model when I'm back home from work!

cool and yes, I think that would make them look more interesting and natural.

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
that looks nice, I definitly agree with ratty about the pipes.
have you thought about baking a mask for behind the panel? Im not sure what app you're using for projection but if you can assign different colours to the high poly model you could bake some masks which could then be selected in photoshop.

What apps are you using?, have you looked into ambient occlusion?

post.author: elusive
post.body:
I think ambient occlusion should be enough to mask the pipes behind the panel for the diffuse. If you have any tipps according to that method just fire
I use Maya and Photoshop for my work.
It has some nice features for texture baking. I'm still trying to figure out how to get the best results. The rest will be painted with a tablet usually.

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
oh ok, theres ao on your textures already? I think I can see it now

I dont have any tips on ao really, but id definitly recommend experimenting with the projection tool in maya, I havent used the maya one personally but im sure its the same, in max I use it to do all sorts of things, from skyboxes to rendering alpha planes and masks and then there are so many ideas I have which I havent even gotten around to trying yet, it can be a very powerful tool.

post.author: Lumpengnom
post.body:
That are some nice textures.

elusive wrote:
Sure I can do that!
Still have to figure out how to bring a round shape for an archway in harmony with non-gothic high tech environment ...


There are lots of good examples for round arch constructions in modern architecture.
Check out Alameda subway station in Valencia by Santiago Calatrava for that. Fosters Faculty of Law in Cambridge is a nice example for a modern arch construction as well. And then there´s an awesome industrial building by Samyn and Partners in Belgium.

All of theser are not the typical doomesque hightech style but you can extrapolate from there.

some more distressed versions of the ones you've already done would look pretty sweet.

post.author: Lumpengnom
post.body:
That are some nice textures.

elusive wrote:
Sure I can do that!
Still have to figure out how to bring a round shape for an archway in harmony with non-gothic high tech environment ...


There are lots of good examples for round arch constructions in modern architecture.
Check out Alameda subway station in Valencia by Santiago Calatrava for that. Fosters Faculty of Law in Cambridge is a nice example for a modern arch construction as well. And then there´s an awesome industrial building by Samyn and Partners in Belgium.

All of theser are not the typical doomesque hightech style but you can extrapolate from there.

th.thHead,th.thSides,th.thTop,th.thLeft,th.thRight,th.thBottom,th.thCornerL,th.thCornerR {
	font-weight: bold; border: #FFFFFF; border-style: solid; height: 28px;
}
td.row3Right,td.spaceRow {
	background-color: #D1D7DC; border: #FFFFFF; border-style: solid;
}

th.thHead,td.catHead { font-size: 12px; border-width: 1px 1px 0px 1px; }
th.thSides,td.catSides,td.spaceRow	 { border-width: 0px 1px 0px 1px; }
th.thRight,td.catRight,td.row3Right	 { border-width: 0px 1px 0px 0px; }
th.thLeft,td.catLeft	  { border-width: 0px 0px 0px 1px; }
th.thBottom,td.catBottom  { border-width: 0px 1px 1px 1px; }
th.thTop	 { border-width: 1px 0px 0px 0px; }
th.thCornerL { border-width: 1px 0px 0px 1px; }
th.thCornerR { border-width: 1px 1px 0px 0px; }

/* The largest text used in the index page title and toptic title etc. */
.maintitle	{
	font-weight: bold; font-size: 22px; font-family: "Trebuchet MS",Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;
	text-decoration: none; line-height : 120%; color : #000000;
}

/* General text */
.gen { font-size : 12px; }
.genmed { font-size : 11px; }
.gensmall { font-size : 10px; }
.gen,.genmed,.gensmall { color : #000000; }
a.gen,a.genmed,a.gensmall { color: #006699; text-decoration: none; }
a.gen:hover,a.genmed:hover,a.gensmall:hover	{ color: #DD6900; text-decoration: underline; }

/* The register, login, search etc links at the top of the page */
.mainmenu		{ font-size : 11px; color : #000000 }
a.mainmenu		{ text-decoration: none; color : #006699;  }
a.mainmenu:hover{ text-decoration: underline; color : #DD6900; }

/* Forum category titles */
.cattitle		{ font-weight: bold; font-size: 12px ; letter-spacing: 1px; color : #006699}
a.cattitle		{ text-decoration: none; color : #006699; }
a.cattitle:hover{ text-decoration: underline; }

/* Forum title: Text and link to the forums used in: index.php */
.forumlink		{ font-weight: bold; font-size: 12px; color : #006699; }
a.forumlink 	{ text-decoration: none; color : #006699; }
a.forumlink:hover{ text-decoration: underline; color : #DD6900; }

/* Used for the navigation text, (Page 1,2,3 etc) and the navigation bar when in a forum */
.nav			{ font-weight: bold; font-size: 11px; color : #000000;}
a.nav			{ text-decoration: none; color : #006699; }
a.nav:hover		{ text-decoration: underline; }

/* titles for the topics: could specify viewed link colour too */
.topictitle,h1,h2	{ font-weight: bold; font-size: 11px; color : #000000; }
a.topictitle:link   { text-decoration: none; color : #006699; }
a.topictitle:visited { text-decoration: none; color : #5493B4; }
a.topictitle:hover	{ text-decoration: underline; color : #DD6900; }

/* Name of poster in viewmsg.php and viewtopic.php and other places */
.name			{ font-size : 11px; color : #000000;}

/* Location, number of posts, post date etc */
.postdetails		{ font-size : 10px; color : #000000; }

/* The content of the posts (body of text) */
.postbody { font-size : 12px; line-height: 18px}
a.postlink:link	{ text-decoration: none; color : #006699 }
a.postlink:visited { text-decoration: none; color : #5493B4; }
a.postlink:hover { text-decoration: underline; color : #DD6900}

/* Quote & Code blocks */
.code {
	font-family: Courier, 'Courier New', sans-serif; font-size: 11px; color: #006600;
	background-color: #FAFAFA; border: #D1D7DC; border-style: solid;
	border-left-width: 1px; border-top-width: 1px; border-right-width: 1px; border-bottom-width: 1px
}

.quote {
	font-family: Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 11px; color: #444444; line-height: 125%;
	background-color: #FAFAFA; border: #D1D7DC; border-style: solid;
	border-left-width: 1px; border-top-width: 1px; border-right-width: 1px; border-bottom-width: 1px
}

/* Copyright and bottom info */
.copyright		{ font-size: 10px; font-family: Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; color: #444444; letter-spacing: -1px;}
a.copyright		{ color: #444444; text-decoration: none;}
a.copyright:hover { color: #000000; text-decoration: underline;}

/* Form elements */
input,textarea, select {
	color : #000000;
	font: normal 11px Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;
	border-color : #000000;
}

/* The text input fields background colour */
input.post, textarea.post, select {
	background-color : #FFFFFF;
}

input { text-indent : 2px; }

/* The buttons used for bbCode styling in message post */
input.button {
	background-color : #EFEFEF;
	color : #000000;
	font-size: 11px; font-family: Verdana, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;
}

/* The main submit button option */
input.mainoption {
	background-color : #FAFAFA;
	font-weight : bold;
}

/* None-bold submit button */
input.liteoption {
	background-color : #FAFAFA;
	font-weight : normal;
}

/* This is the line in the posting page which shows the rollover
  help line. This is actually a text box, but if set to be the same
  colour as the background no one will know ;)
*/
.helpline { background-color: #DEE3E7; border-style: none; }

/* Import the fancy styles for IE only (NS4.x doesn't use the @import function) */
@import url("https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516/http://doom3world.org/phpbb2/templates/subSilver/formIE.css");

function getElementX2(obj) {
	var thing = jQuery(obj);
	if((thing == undefined) 
			|| (typeof thing == "undefined") 
			|| (typeof thing.offset == "undefined")) {
		return getElementX(obj);
	}
	return Math.round(thing.offset().left);
}
function trackMouseMove(event,element) {

   var eventX = getEventX(event);
   var elementX = getElementX2(element);
   var xOff = eventX - elementX;
	if(xOff < 0) {
		xOff = 0;
	} else if(xOff > imgWidth) {
		xOff = imgWidth;
	}
   var monthOff = xOff % yearImgWidth;

   var year = Math.floor(xOff / yearImgWidth);
	var yearStart = year * yearImgWidth;
   var monthOfYear = Math.floor(monthOff / monthImgWidth);
   if(monthOfYear > 11) {
       monthOfYear = 11;
   }
   // 1 extra border pixel at the left edge of the year:
   var month = (year * 12) + monthOfYear;
   var day = 1;
	if(monthOff % 2 == 1) {
		day = 15;
	}
	var dateString = 
		zeroPad(year + firstYear) + 
		zeroPad(monthOfYear+1,2) +
		zeroPad(day,2) + "000000";

	var monthString = prettyMonths[monthOfYear];

       var mtOff = year + (month * monthImgWidth) + 1;
       document.getElementById("wbMouseTrackMonthImg").style.left = mtOff + "px";
       curMonth = month;
   }
}

			</tr><tr><td colspan="2"><hr/></td>
			</tr><tr><td colspan="2"><span class="postbody">elusive, its cool but I would make the exposed pipes less straight, ie have more bends in them.
<br/><br/>
also I'm not sure about the wires coming out of one panel opening and leading into another, I think I would of made them hang out of just the one on the left.
<br/><br/>
keep up the good work though, this will look very impressive when finished <img src="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516im_/http://doom3world.org/phpbb2/images/smiles/icon_smile.gif" alt="Smile" border="0"/><br/>_________________<br/><a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/viewtopic.php?t=17180&postdays=0&postorder=asc&start=0" target="_blank" class="postlink">(wip) ratty d3 hell map</a>

				<td valign="top" nowrap="nowrap"><a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516/http://doom3world.org/phpbb2/posting.php?mode=quote&p=174934&sid=cbe28c58dfefb886b563aff040f02478"><img src="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516im_/http://doom3world.org/phpbb2/templates/subSilver/images/lang_english/icon_quote.gif" alt="Reply with quote" title="Reply with quote" border="0"/></a>   </td>
			</tr><tr><td colspan="2"><hr/></td>
			</tr><tr><td colspan="2"><span class="postbody">Thanks for the suggestion and comments!
<br/><br/>
@ratty redemption
<br/>
You mean I should add a curve to two of the pipes behind? If so no problem <img src="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516im_/http://doom3world.org/phpbb2/images/smiles/icon_wink.gif" alt="Wink" border="0"/><br/>
I'll experiment with those cables a bit. I'll show an update to the model when I'm back home from work!<br/>_________________<br/>Where is the life we have lost in living?
<br/>
Where is the wisdom we have lost in knowledge?
<br/>
Where is the knowledge we have lost in information?</span><span class="gensmall"/></td>

post.author: Skutarth
post.body:
Move some of your scratches from the diffuse to the specular map.
Since a lot of these are metal, it makes sense for the scratches to sheen.

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
elusive wrote:
Dents, scratches and flaked off paint are all done using a heightmap. The basic structure comes from the normalmap.
In some cases I use a detail texture to give them a look like in UT.

Quote:
some more distressed versions of the ones you've already done would look pretty sweet.


Do you mean some versions which look more rotten?


yeah, maybe you could wear them down even more, remove some parts/panels of the textures exposing cables/machinery behind them, go a bit deeper into the wall these panels are covering.
You've got some realy nice base models/textures to play around with and I think this whole theme you're working on could be developed alot further with some experimentation.

post.author: elusive
post.body:
@Skutarth
Yes. I usually do that but sometimes the results are not clearly visible in Doom. I'll work on that.

@mikebart
Good points! That makes me curious how it would look like ingame ;D

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body: elusive, I really like mikebart's suggestion, that could also be interesting to see bump mapped cables and machine parts behind some of the removed panels. you might even consider coloring them differently, so the cables were even more obvious. all up to you of course but I'd like to see some tests at least

post.author: elusive
post.body:
I'll work on it as far as possible!
Doing cables and complex tech stuff behind wall panel is a bit more to model than a plane with some extruded faces

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body: understood and at least you like mikebart's suggestion

post.author: elusive
post.body:
Alright I started making such a kind of model that has some pipes and stuff behind a panel.
It still needs details but I'd like to show you what I got so far

post.author: Bo$bevok
post.body:
omg thats gonna look so awesome ingame...
keep up the good work

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body:
elusive, its cool but I would make the exposed pipes less straight, ie have more bends in them.

also I'm not sure about the wires coming out of one panel opening and leading into another, I think I would of made them hang out of just the one on the left.

keep up the good work though, this will look very impressive when finished

post.author: elusive
post.body:
Thanks for the suggestion and comments!

@ratty redemption
You mean I should add a curve to two of the pipes behind? If so no problem
I'll experiment with those cables a bit. I'll show an update to the model when I'm back home from work!

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body:
elusive wrote:
You mean I should add a curve to two of the pipes behind? If so no problem
I'll experiment with those cables a bit. I'll show an update to the model when I'm back home from work!

cool and yes, I think that would make them look more interesting and natural.

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
that looks nice, I definitly agree with ratty about the pipes.
have you thought about baking a mask for behind the panel? Im not sure what app you're using for projection but if you can assign different colours to the high poly model you could bake some masks which could then be selected in photoshop.

What apps are you using?, have you looked into ambient occlusion?

post.author: elusive
post.body:
I think ambient occlusion should be enough to mask the pipes behind the panel for the diffuse. If you have any tipps according to that method just fire
I use Maya and Photoshop for my work.
It has some nice features for texture baking. I'm still trying to figure out how to get the best results. The rest will be painted with a tablet usually.

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
oh ok, theres ao on your textures already? I think I can see it now

I dont have any tips on ao really, but id definitly recommend experimenting with the projection tool in maya, I havent used the maya one personally but im sure its the same, in max I use it to do all sorts of things, from skyboxes to rendering alpha planes and masks and then there are so many ideas I have which I havent even gotten around to trying yet, it can be a very powerful tool.

post.author: elusive
post.body: While working on the "cable behind the panel" stuff I did a few more other textures

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body: very nice, I especially like the bumps on this one

post.author: Tron
post.body: Oh, I like. Quake 1 Base style but just updated.

keep up the good work though, this will look very impressive when finished

post.date: Posted: Tue Apr 03, 2007 8:31 am Post subject:
post.author: mikebart
post.body:
that looks nice, I definitly agree with ratty about the pipes.
have you thought about baking a mask for behind the panel? Im not sure what app you're using for projection but if you can assign different colours to the high poly model you could bake some masks which could then be selected in photoshop.

What apps are you using?, have you looked into ambient occlusion?
_________________
Tutorial; Baking Multiple Maps in 3dsmax8.

post.body:
I think ambient occlusion should be enough to mask the pipes behind the panel for the diffuse. If you have any tipps according to that method just fire
I use Maya and Photoshop for my work.
It has some nice features for texture baking. I'm still trying to figure out how to get the best results. The rest will be painted with a tablet usually.

//<![CDATA[
var firstDate = 820454400000;
var lastDate = 1420070399999;
var wbPrefix = "/web/";
var wbCurrentUrl = "http:\/\/doom3world.org\/phpbb2\/viewtopic.php?p=174947";

var curYear = -1;
var curMonth = -1;
var yearCount = 18;
var firstYear = 1996;
var imgWidth = 475;
var yearImgWidth = 25;
var monthImgWidth = 2;
var trackerVal = "none";
var displayDay = "9";
var displayMonth = "May";
var displayYear = "2007";
var prettyMonths = ["Jan","Feb","Mar","Apr","May","Jun","Jul","Aug","Sep","Oct","Nov","Dec"];

function showTrackers(val) {
	if(val == trackerVal) {
		return;
	}
	if(val == "inline") {
		document.getElementById("displayYearEl").style.color = "#ec008c";
		document.getElementById("displayMonthEl").style.color = "#ec008c";
		document.getElementById("displayDayEl").style.color = "#ec008c";		
	} else {
		document.getElementById("displayYearEl").innerHTML = displayYear;
		document.getElementById("displayYearEl").style.color = "#ff0";
		document.getElementById("displayMonthEl").innerHTML = displayMonth;
		document.getElementById("displayMonthEl").style.color = "#ff0";
		document.getElementById("displayDayEl").innerHTML = displayDay;
		document.getElementById("displayDayEl").style.color = "#ff0";
	}
   document.getElementById("wbMouseTrackYearImg").style.display = val;
   document.getElementById("wbMouseTrackMonthImg").style.display = val;
   trackerVal = val;
}
function getElementX2(obj) {
	var thing = jQuery(obj);
	if((thing == undefined) 
			|| (typeof thing == "undefined") 
			|| (typeof thing.offset == "undefined")) {
		return getElementX(obj);
	}
	return Math.round(thing.offset().left);
}
function trackMouseMove(event,element) {

   var eventX = getEventX(event);
   var elementX = getElementX2(element);
   var xOff = eventX - elementX;
	if(xOff < 0) {
		xOff = 0;
	} else if(xOff > imgWidth) {
		xOff = imgWidth;
	}
   var monthOff = xOff % yearImgWidth;

   var year = Math.floor(xOff / yearImgWidth);
	var yearStart = year * yearImgWidth;
   var monthOfYear = Math.floor(monthOff / monthImgWidth);
   if(monthOfYear > 11) {
       monthOfYear = 11;
   }
   // 1 extra border pixel at the left edge of the year:
   var month = (year * 12) + monthOfYear;
   var day = 1;
	if(monthOff % 2 == 1) {
		day = 15;
	}
	var dateString = 
		zeroPad(year + firstYear) + 
		zeroPad(monthOfYear+1,2) +
		zeroPad(day,2) + "000000";

	var monthString = prettyMonths[monthOfYear];
	document.getElementById("displayYearEl").innerHTML = year + 1996;
	document.getElementById("displayMonthEl").innerHTML = monthString;
	// looks too jarring when it changes..
	//document.getElementById("displayDayEl").innerHTML = zeroPad(day,2);

	var url = wbPrefix + dateString + '/' +  wbCurrentUrl;
	document.getElementById('wm-graph-anchor').href = url;

   //document.getElementById("wmtbURL").value="evX("+eventX+") elX("+elementX+") xO("+xOff+") y("+year+") m("+month+") monthOff("+monthOff+") DS("+dateString+") Moy("+monthOfYear+") ms("+monthString+")";
   if(curYear != year) {
       var yrOff = year * yearImgWidth;
       document.getElementById("wbMouseTrackYearImg").style.left = yrOff + "px";
       curYear = year;
   }
   if(curMonth != month) {
       var mtOff = year + (month * monthImgWidth) + 1;
       document.getElementById("wbMouseTrackMonthImg").style.left = mtOff + "px";
       curMonth = month;
   }
}
//]]]] ><![CDATA[>

			</tr><tr><td colspan="2"><span class="postbody">Move some of your scratches from the diffuse to the specular map.

			</tr><tr><td colspan="2"><span class="postbody"/><table width="90%" cellspacing="1" cellpadding="3" border="0" align="center"><tr><td><span class="genmed"><b>elusive wrote:</b></span></td>	</tr><tr><td class="quote">Dents, scratches and flaked off paint are all done using a heightmap. The basic structure comes from the normalmap. 
<br/>
In some cases I use a detail texture to give them a look like in UT.
<br/><br/><table width="90%" cellspacing="1" cellpadding="3" border="0" align="center"><tr><td><span class="genmed"><b>Quote:</b></span></td>	</tr><tr><td class="quote">some more distressed versions of the ones you've already done would look pretty sweet.</td>	</tr></table><span class="postbody">
<br/><br/>
Do you mean some versions which look more rotten?</span></td>	</tr></table><span class="postbody">
<br/><br/>
yeah, maybe you could wear them down even more, remove some parts/panels of the textures exposing cables/machinery behind them, go a bit deeper into the wall these panels are covering.
<br/>
You've got some realy nice base models/textures to play around with and I think this whole theme you're working on could be developed alot further with some experimentation.<br/>_________________<br/><a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/viewtopic.php?p=160978#160978" target="_blank" class="postlink">Tutorial; Baking Multiple Maps in 3dsmax8. </a></span><span class="gensmall"/></td>

<br/><br/>

			</tr><tr><td colspan="2"><span class="postbody">that looks nice, I definitly agree with ratty about the pipes.
<br/>
have you thought about baking a mask for behind the panel? Im not sure what app you're using for projection but if you can assign different colours to the high poly model you could bake some masks which could then be selected in photoshop.
<br/><br/>
What apps are you using?, have you looked into ambient occlusion?<br/>_________________<br/><a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20070509181516/http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/viewtopic.php?p=160978#160978" target="_blank" class="postlink">Tutorial; Baking Multiple Maps in 3dsmax8. </a></span><span class="gensmall"/></td>

post.author: Skutarth
post.body:
Move some of your scratches from the diffuse to the specular map.
Since a lot of these are metal, it makes sense for the scratches to sheen.

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
elusive wrote:
Dents, scratches and flaked off paint are all done using a heightmap. The basic structure comes from the normalmap.
In some cases I use a detail texture to give them a look like in UT.

Quote:
some more distressed versions of the ones you've already done would look pretty sweet.


Do you mean some versions which look more rotten?


yeah, maybe you could wear them down even more, remove some parts/panels of the textures exposing cables/machinery behind them, go a bit deeper into the wall these panels are covering.
You've got some realy nice base models/textures to play around with and I think this whole theme you're working on could be developed alot further with some experimentation.

post.author: elusive
post.body:
@Skutarth
Yes. I usually do that but sometimes the results are not clearly visible in Doom. I'll work on that.

@mikebart
Good points! That makes me curious how it would look like ingame ;D

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body: elusive, I really like mikebart's suggestion, that could also be interesting to see bump mapped cables and machine parts behind some of the removed panels. you might even consider coloring them differently, so the cables were even more obvious. all up to you of course but I'd like to see some tests at least

post.author: elusive
post.body:
I'll work on it as far as possible!
Doing cables and complex tech stuff behind wall panel is a bit more to model than a plane with some extruded faces

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body: understood and at least you like mikebart's suggestion

post.author: elusive
post.body:
Alright I started making such a kind of model that has some pipes and stuff behind a panel.
It still needs details but I'd like to show you what I got so far

post.author: Bo$bevok
post.body:
omg thats gonna look so awesome ingame...
keep up the good work

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body:
elusive, its cool but I would make the exposed pipes less straight, ie have more bends in them.

also I'm not sure about the wires coming out of one panel opening and leading into another, I think I would of made them hang out of just the one on the left.

keep up the good work though, this will look very impressive when finished

post.author: elusive
post.body:
Thanks for the suggestion and comments!

@ratty redemption
You mean I should add a curve to two of the pipes behind? If so no problem
I'll experiment with those cables a bit. I'll show an update to the model when I'm back home from work!

post.author: ratty redemption
post.body:
elusive wrote:
You mean I should add a curve to two of the pipes behind? If so no problem
I'll experiment with those cables a bit. I'll show an update to the model when I'm back home from work!

cool and yes, I think that would make them look more interesting and natural.

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
that looks nice, I definitly agree with ratty about the pipes.
have you thought about baking a mask for behind the panel? Im not sure what app you're using for projection but if you can assign different colours to the high poly model you could bake some masks which could then be selected in photoshop.

What apps are you using?, have you looked into ambient occlusion?

post.author: elusive
post.body:
I think ambient occlusion should be enough to mask the pipes behind the panel for the diffuse. If you have any tipps according to that method just fire
I use Maya and Photoshop for my work.
It has some nice features for texture baking. I'm still trying to figure out how to get the best results. The rest will be painted with a tablet usually.

post.author: mikebart
post.body:
oh ok, theres ao on your textures already? I think I can see it now

I dont have any tips on ao really, but id definitly recommend experimenting with the projection tool in maya, I havent used the maya one personally but im sure its the same, in max I use it to do all sorts of things, from skyboxes to rendering alpha planes and masks and then there are so many ideas I have which I havent even gotten around to trying yet, it can be a very powerful tool.

post.author: elusive
post.body: While working on the "cable behind the panel" stuff I did a few more other textures
